unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about managing gastritis, right? Let me tell you about my own experience. I had terrible stomach pain for months. Initially, I self-medicated with antacids – ENO, Gelusil, the works! – thinking it was just acidity. But the pain persisted. It was a burning sensation, especially after eating spicy food (which, let’s be honest, is pretty much every meal in our house!). I even tried some home remedies my nani told me about – ginger and ajwain. Nothing seemed to give me lasting relief.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about managing gastritis, right? Let me tell you about my own experience. I had terrible stomach pain for months. Initially, I self-medicated with antacids – E-N-O, Gelusil, the works! – thinking it was just acidity. But the pain persisted. It was a burning sensation, especially after eating spicy food (which, let’s be honest, is pretty much every meal in our house!). I even tried some home remedies my nani told me about – ginger and ajwain. Nothing seemed to give me lasting relief.

unnormalised: Finally, my wife Aisha insisted I see a Dr. We went to a gastroenterologist, Dr. Sharma, at Fortis Hospital. After explaining my symptoms and a quick physical exam, she suspected gastritis and recommended an endoscopy. Honestly, I was terrified! But the procedure itself wasn't as bad as I imagined. It took around 30 mins.
normalised: Finally, my wife Aisha insisted I see a Doctor. We went to a gastroenterologist, Doctor Sharma, at Fortis Hospital. After explaining my symptoms and a quick physical exam, she suspected gastritis and recommended an endoscopy. Honestly, I was terrified! But the procedure itself wasn't as bad as I imagined. It took around thirty minutes.

unnormalised: The endoscopy confirmed I had gastritis, and it turned out I also had a H. pylori infection. Dr. Sharma prescribed a course of antibiotics and PPIs (proton pump inhibitors) – specifically, Omeprazole 20mg twice a day and two other medications I can't quite recall the names of now. Plus, a strict diet. No more spicy food, no caffeine (chai was a struggle!), and no alcohol. She also advised lifestyle changes like stress reduction, as stress can aggravate gastritis.
normalised: The endoscopy confirmed I had gastritis, and it turned out I also had a H. pylori infection. Doctor Sharma prescribed a course of antibiotics and P-P-Is (proton pump inhibitors) – specifically, Omeprazole twenty milligram twice a day and two other medications I can't quite recall the names of now. Plus, a strict diet. No more spicy food, no caffeine (chai was a struggle!), and no alcohol. She also advised lifestyle changes like stress reduction, as stress can aggravate gastritis.

unnormalised: It took a few weeks, but I started feeling much better. I still have occasional flare-ups if I cheat on my diet (hello, samosas!), but overall, my stomach is much happier. So, my advice? Don't ignore persistent stomach pain. See a gastroenterologist, get the proper diagnosis, and follow their treatment plan. Self-treating might provide temporary relief, but you could be masking a bigger problem. Good luck!
